official-title.#text:
To require any State which, after enacting a
		  Congressional redistricting plan after a decennial census and apportionment of
		  Representatives, enacts a subsequent Congressional redistricting plan prior to
		  the next decennial census and apportionment of Representatives, to obtain a
		  declaratory judgment or preclearance in the manner provided under section 5 of
		  the Voting Rights Act of 1965 in order for the subsequent plan to take
		  effect.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Redistricting and Voter Protection Act
			 of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text:
Requiring declaratory
			 judgment or preclearance as prerequisite for multiple congressional
			 redistricting plans enacted pursuant to same decennial census and apportionment
			 of representatives

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, after a State enacts a Congressional redistricting plan in the
			 manner provided by law after an apportionment of Representatives under
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Redistricting and Voter Protection Act of 2013/s:2/ss:b

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, any
			 subsequent Congressional redistricting plan enacted by the State prior to the
			 next apportionment of Representatives under such section shall not take effect
			 unless and until—

quote.#text:
An Act to provide for the fifteenth and
			 subsequent decennial censuses and to provide for an apportionment of
			 Representatives in Congress

header.#text:
Declaratory
			 Judgment that Plan Does Not Deny or Abridge Right To Vote on Account of Race or
			 Color

text.#text:
the State commences a civil action in the
			 United States District Court for the District of Columbia for a declaratory
			 judgment that such subsequent plan neither has the purpose nor will have the
			 effect of denying or abridging the right to vote on account of race or color,
			 or in contravention of the guarantees set forth in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 4(f)(2) of the
			 Voting Rights Act of 1965

text.#text:
the court enters
			 such a declaratory judgment.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Redistricting and Voter Protection Act of 2013/s:2/ss:a

text.#text:
A
			 subsequent Congressional redistricting plan described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has not interposed an objection
			 within 60 days of such submission; or

text.#text:
the chief legal
			 officer or other appropriate official of the State involved submits the plan to
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has affirmatively indicated that such objection will not
			 be made.

text.#text:
upon good cause
			 shown, to facilitate an expedited approval within 60 days of such submission,
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Redistricting and Voter Protection Act of 2013/s:2/ss:a

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, and the proceedings related to such judgment or preclearance,
			 shall be treated as a declaratory judgment or preclearance under
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Redistricting and Voter Protection Act of 2013/s:2/ss:b

header.#text:
Application of
			 Voting Rights Act of 1965

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
does not apply with respect to any
			 subsequent Congressional redistricting plan described in section 1(a) if the
			 plan is enacted by a State pursuant to a court order in order to comply with
			 the Constitution or to enforce the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Redistricting and Voter Protection Act of 2013/s:1

header.#text:
No
			 effect on redistricting plans enacted pursuant to court order
